section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to build background, and introduce vocabulary (tiny, surface).
Begin Story Time by introducing the book and asking, What can water turn into?
Read for enjoyment and understanding, noticing vocabulary in context.
Check understanding, differentiating as needed.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Join in singing, rhyming, and word play.
Know that people can speak different languages; Understand and use some words or phrases in another language.
Talk and share.
Use information to categorize; Use information to compare and contrast.
Separate syllables from a word.
Investigate, describe, and talk about materials from the earth and how they are used.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Ask children to look at pictures of water and say if the water is a lake, a river, a cloud, rain, or dew.
Invite children to think of other places where they could find water and say what they know about it.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_essential-question: How can we care for our world?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: What does that book tell you about Earth?
Pretend you are a scientist. What will you investigate?
Tell me what you know about water.
Can you write the word tiny and decorate and color around it?
Draw a picture of an ocean. What colors will you use?
What sound do you hear at the beginning of the word tiny? What letter makes that sound?
What can you build that could be used to carry water?

section-block.tg_learning-goal-body: Mind Builders: Executive Function; Motivation and Creativity

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to share the Mind Builder persist in tasks and to introduce vocabulary (experiment, deep).
Begin Story Time by connecting the Mind Builder to Water, Little Water.
Read closely to notice and talk about the Mind Builder.
Offer an extended play opportunity.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Use appropriate tone of voice.
Understand a large number of words and begin to use more and more of those words.
Persist in tasks.
Take initiative.
Ask and answer questions about story elements.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Talk about persisting at a task to reach a goal.
Ask children to look at pictures of people trying to do different things, and describe what they are trying to do.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_essential-question: How can we care for our world?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: Can you show me a picture of water in the book?
Pretend you are taking pictures. Describe what you are taking pictures of.
What happens to water when it goes really cold?
Can you show me how to write the word deep using foam letters?
Draw a picture of some of the fun things you can do in water.
Can you think of a word that starts with the same letter as the word deep?
Can you build something that you would see in the water?

TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved.

section-block.tg_learning-goal-body: Language: World Languages; Conversation; Sentence Structure

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to share the comprehension skill Use Cognates and introduce vocabulary (roots, dew) .
Begin Story Time by revisiting Water, Little Water and asking the guiding question, What do we know about Little Water?
Read interactively for deeper comprehension.
Check understanding and differentiate as needed.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Understand and use some words or phrases in another language.
Use language for different purposes and match language to social contexts; Use appropriate tone of voice.
Recognize and understand common cognates.
Persist in tasks.
Use art for self-expression.
Understand differences between living and non-living things.
Observe, investigate, describe, and talk about common objects.

section-block.tg_learning-goal-body: Mind Builders: Executive Function; Motivation and Creativity

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Ask children to look at a picture, identify what they see in the picture, and then guess what the cognate is for that word.
Say a Spanish cognate and have children guess the matching English cognate.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_essential-question: How can we care for our world?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: How did that book help you learn more about Earth?
Pretend you are a river. How would you move?
How can you measure how much water is in a container?
Write or draw how it feels to splash in cold water.
Can you show how water looks in the ocean?
What letters do you see around the classroom?
Build a tree with long roots. What materials will you use?

section-block.tg_copyright-line: TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. Water, Little Water by Jorge Argueta, illustrated by Felipe Ugalde Alcántara. Text copyright © 2017 by Jorge Argueta. Illustrations copyright © 2017 by Felipe Ugalde Alcántara. Published by Scholastic Inc. by arrangement with Piñata Books, an imprint of Arte Público Press.
TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved.

tg_materials-caption.tg_materials-caption_book-title-Ital: Big Chart of Big Ideas: You Can Help

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to talk about what children have learned about water and to introduce vocabulary (Earth, recycle).
Begin Story Time by connecting the texts You Can Help and Water, Little Water.
Read interactively and connect to this week’s concept question, How can we care for our world?
Offer an extended play opportunity.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Use appropriate tone of voice.
Persist in tasks
Classify and organize to group and arrange items.
Separate syllables from a word.
Show understanding and the importance of taking care of the planet.
Observe, investigate, describe, and talk about common objects.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Guide children to look at pictures, identify the objects, and say if they should be recycled.
Invite children to talk about how they recycle at home.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_essential-question: How can we care for our world?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: What do you like most about this book?
Pretend you are sorting cans and paper into separate containers.
Can you sort five objects from biggest to smallest?
Can you write a story about how water goes from the ocean to the sky?
Draw a picture of a river. What colors will you use?
What letter do you hear at the beginning of the word water? What can you find in the room that also starts with that letter?
Use blocks to build a recycling bin.

section-block.tg_copyright-line: TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. Water, Little Water by Jorge Argueta, illustrated by Felipe Ugalde Alcántara. Text copyright © 2017 by Jorge Argueta. Illustrations copyright © 2017 by Felipe Ugalde Alcántara. Published by Scholastic Inc. by arrangement with Piñata Books, an imprint of Arte Público Press.
TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to introduce vocabulary (river, ocean).
Begin Story Time by revisiting the book and asking, How does Little Water move from Earth to the sky?
Read and retell interactively for physical engagement an imagination.
Check understanding and differentiate as needed.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Use appropriate tone of voice.
Understand and use some words or phrases in another language.
Persist in tasks.
Take initiative.
Use information to describe.
Write for different purposes.
Show understanding and the importance of taking care of the planet.

section-block.tg_learning-goal-body: Mind Builders: Executive Function; Motivation and Creativity

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Support children as they independently respond to this week’s prompt, What would you do to take care of your neighborhood?
Differentiate and modify as needed.
Save children’s writing to display next week.

section-block.tg_essential-question: How can we care for our world?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: What other books would you like to read about Earth?
Imagine you are Little Water climbing from deep in Earth to the surface.
Which body of water is bigger, a lake or an ocean?
Imagine a story about water that can talk. What would it say?
Can you draw a picture of Little Water’s journey?
Imagine a name for an ocean. What sound does it start with? What letter makes that sound?
Can you create something that can hold water?

section-block.tg_copyright-line: TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. Water, Little Water by Jorge Argueta, illustrated by Felipe Ugalde Alcántara. Text copyright © 2017 by Jorge Argueta. Illustrations copyright © 2017 by Felipe Ugalde Alcántara. Published by Scholastic Inc. by arrangement with Piñata Books, an imprint of Arte Público Press.
TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Investigate and demonstrate growing understanding of the sounds and intonation of language.

section-block.tg_skills-focus_body: World Languages: Increase listening vocabulary and begin to develop vocabulary of object names and common phrases in English. (ELL) (TX.II.D.6)

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Talk and share.
Use information learned from books by describing, relating, categorizing, or comparing and contrasting.
Can segment a syllable from a word.
Observe, investigate, describe, and discuss earth materials and their properties and uses.
Match language to social contexts.
Investigate and demonstrate growing understanding of the sounds and intonation of language.
Demonstrate understanding in a variety of ways or knowing the meaning of 3,000 to 4,000 words, many more than used.
Show initiative in independent situations and persist in attempting to solve problems.
Initiate problem-solving strategies and seek adult help when necessary.
Ask and respond to questions relevant to the text read aloud.

section-block.tg_skills-focus_body: World Languages: Increase listening vocabulary and begin to develop vocabulary of object names and common phrases in English. (ELL) (TX.II.D.6)

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Provide appropriate information for various situations.
Investigate and demonstrate growing understanding of the sounds and intonation of language.
Show initiative in independent situations and persist in attempting to solve problems.
Use art as a form of creative self-expression and representation.
Observe, investigate, describe, and discuss the relationships of organisms to their environments.
Observe, investigate, describe, and discuss properties and characteristics of common objects.
Match language to social contexts.
Investigate and demonstrate growing understanding of the sounds and intonation of language.
Show initiative in independent situations and persist in attempting to solve problems.
Classify and organize to group and arrange items.
Can segment a syllable from a word.
Demonstrate the importance of caring for our environment and our planet.
Observe, investigate, describe, and discuss properties and characteristics of common objects.
Match language to social context.

section-block.tg_skills-focus_body: World Languages: Child increases listening vocabulary and begins to develop vocabulary of object names and common phrases in English. (ELL) (TX.II.D.6)

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Show initiative in independent situations and persists in attempting to solve problems.
Initiate problem-solving strategies and seek adult help when necessary.
Use information learned from books by describing, relating, categorizing, or comparing and contrasting.
Independently write to communicate ideas for a variety of purposes.
Demonstrate the importance of caring for our environment and our planet.
